a tiara, i.e. official turban (of a king or high priest)
to be high actively, to rise or raise (in various applications, literally or figuratively)
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
to soar, i.e. be lofty; figuratively, to be haughty
to depress or sink (expectation figuratively, to humiliate, intransitive or transitive)

27.brief: to put (used in a great variety of applications, literal, figurative, inferentially, and elliptically)
properly, assemblage; used only adverbially also, even, yea, though; often repeated as correl. both...and
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
to exist, i.e. be or become, come to pass (always emphatic, and not a mere copula or auxiliary)
as far (or long, or much) as, whether of space (even unto) or time (during, while, until) or degree (equally with)
to go or come (in a wide variety of applications)
who, which, what, that; also (as an adverb and a conjunction) when, where, how, because, in order that, etc.

properly, a verdict (favorable or unfavorable) pronounced judicially, especially a sentence or formal decree (human or (participant's) divine law, individual or collective), including the act, the place, the suit, the crime, and the penalty; abstractly, justice, including a participant's right or privilege (statutory or customary), or even a style
to give, used with greatest latitude of application (put, make, etc.)

a son (as a builder of the family name), in the widest sense (of literal and figurative relationship, including grandson, subject, nation, quality or condition, etc., (like father or brother), etc.)
ruddy i.e. a human being (an individual or the species, mankind, etc.)

properly, something slaughtered; hence, a beast (or meat, as butchered); abstractly butchery (or concretely, a place of slaughter)
to polish; by implication, to make bald (the head), to gall (the shoulder); also, to sharpen
to eat (literally or figuratively)
properly, heed, i.e. purpose; used only adverbially, on account of (as a motive or an aim), teleologically, in order that
lightning; by analogy, a gleam; concretely, a flashing sword

29.brief: to gaze at; mentally to perceive, contemplate (with pleasure); specifically, to have avision of
evil (as destructive), literally (ruin) or morally (especially guile); figuratively idolatry (as false, subjective), uselessness (as deceptive, objective; also adverbially, in vain)
properly, to distribute, i.e. determine by lot or magical scroll; by implication, to divine
to give, used with greatest latitude of application (put, make, etc.)
properly, self (but generally used to point out more definitely the object of a verb or preposition, even or namely)
near, with or among; often in general, to
the back of the neck (as that on which burdens are bound)
morally wrong; concretely, an (actively) bad person

to go or come (in a wide variety of applications)
a day (as the warm hours), whether literal (from sunrise to sunset, or from one sunset to the next), or figurative (a space of time defined by an associated term), (often used adverb)
time, especially (adverb with preposition) now, when, etc.
an extremity; adverbially (with prepositional prefix) after

30.brief: to turn back (hence, away) transitively or intransitively, literally or figuratively (not necessarily with the idea of return to the starting point); generally to retreat; often adverbial, again
near, with or among; often in general, to
a knife or razor (as making bare); also a scabbard (as being bare, i.e. empty)
properly, a standing, i.e. a spot; but used widely of a locality (general or specific); also (figuratively) of a condition (of body or mind)
who, which, what, that; also (as an adverb and a conjunction) when, where, how, because, in order that, etc.
(absolutely) to create; (qualified) to cut down (a wood), select, feed (as formative processes)
the earth (at large, or partitively a land)
to judge, i.e. pronounce sentence (for or against); by implication, to vindicate or punish; by extenssion, to govern; passively, to litigate (literally or figuratively)
properly, self (but generally used to point out more definitely the object of a verb or preposition, even or namely)

31.brief: to spill forth (blood, a libation, liquid metal; or even a solid, i.e. to mound up); also (figuratively) to expend (life, soul, complaint, money, etc.); intensively, to sprawl out
above, over, upon, or against (yet always in this last relation with a downward aspect) in a great variety of applications
strictly froth at the mouth, i.e. (figuratively) fury (especially of God's displeasure with sin)
to puff, i.e. blow with the breath or air; hence, to fan (as a breeze), to utter, to kindle (a fire), to scoff
above, over, upon, or against (yet always in this last relation with a downward aspect) in a great variety of applications

a man as an individual or a male person; often used as an adjunct to a more definite term (and in such cases frequently not expressed in translation)
to kindle, i.e. consume (by fire or by eating);  to be(-come) brutish
destructive, i.e. (as noun) destruction, literally (specifically a snare) or figuratively (corruption)

blood (as that which when shed causes death) of man or an animal; by analogy, the juice of the grape; figuratively (especially in the plural) bloodshed (i.e. drops of blood)

perhaps properly, to arrange; but used figuratively (of words), to speak; rarely (in a destructive sense) to subdue
